posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, This is my first year using OpenCV and so far I have found it wildly intuitive to perform Vision Processing on an rPi (we are using Java, by the way). I have been using it for detecting the angle and position of the game pieces (cone, cube) and for the cube it is working great. For the cone it is working efficiently, and it is returning an angle… but not the one that we want. minAreaRect by default has a range between [0, 90), but we would like something between 0 and 180, or -90 to 90. I believe that it would have something to do with the relative lengths of the width and height of the minAreaRect Rectangle itself (or possibly the always-upright bounding box) but thus far nothing that I have tried has worked. I feel like I’m on the verge of figuring it out but I think getting an opinion from someone who has been using OpenCV longer would be better. I would appreciate any help, and thank you!

Note that the reason it is “working” for the cube is because for that we really only need a range between [0, 90) due to its rotational symmetry.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
You seem to understand the change in angle because of the change in orientation of upright versus sideways so I’m not sure what your question still is.

But maybe what you really want is to use OpenCV minEnclosingTriangle() for a cone.

If you still need help on the calculation of the angle, this SO might help. There are a few solutions that might work for you.

opencv, angle

asked by user349026 on 06:26PM - 11 Apr 13 UTC

link_counts.title: opencv - MinAreaRect angles - Unsure about the angle returned - Stack Overflow

posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked: Thanks for responding so quickly! I have seen this post before, and so far it doesn’t seem to be working when I apply the exact same logic… I was thinking of another idea, however: creating a convexHull object for the cone target, and getting the side lengths of each side of the convexHull . With that, I’d find the shortest side, and that side would have to be the tip of the cone. Depending on where that segment is relative to the center (the midpoint of that side compared to the center of the cone), that would tell me if it’s in the first, second, third, or fourth quadrant, allowing me to easily calculate the angle between 0 and 180 or -90 and 90, as opposed to 0 to 90… Is it possible to create a convexHull object as opposed to just drawing one, allowing me to extract information from it? what do you think? Thanks once again for the guidance!

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Careful here, convex hull will easily return a shape with more than 3 sides, so sorting the segments in this mater will be tricky at best.

posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked:
Thank you for the information! Just to clarify, I would like the angle of the target (cone) between 0 and 180, -90 and 90, or even (ideally), 0 to 360 degrees. I’m sure that this would have to do with differentiating the tip of the cone compared to the rest of the cone, so do you have any more efficient ideas as to how I could access that w/o using the convexHull ?

In regards to your other recommendation, @SLAB-Mr.Thomas , I noticed that minEnclosingTriangle is a void method in that it doesn’t return on object  - it simply draws on the original image. I was scrubbing through the documentation, and, for the life of me, I could not find anything explaining how to get a triangle object. Perhaps I should find the midpoint of one of the sides? But that wouldn’t work since the tip of the cone will switch between segments of the rectangle as it rotates around. Thank you all once again!

Sincerely, Rohan

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I can’t try a test program right now for OpenCV Java minEnclosingTriangle. The documentation I see and it’s consistent with all the other OpenCV methods I’ve used is the results are returned in an output Mat that is an argument of the method call.

The triangle is 3 2-D points. See answered question for usage.

minEnclosingTriangle

public static double minEnclosingTriangle( Mat points, Mat triangle)

I'm using opencv-400.jar and I'm trying to call the method minEnclosingTriangle in the following way. System.loadLibrary(Core.NATIVE_LIBRARY_NAME); Mat points = Mat.zeros(4, 2, CvType.CV_32F); points.put(1, 0, 1); points.put(2, 1, 1); points.put(3,...

link_counts.title: Imgproc.minEnclosingTriangle from Java [closed] - OpenCV Q&A Forum

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Minimum enclosing triangle or an approx bounding polygon seem like the correct option(s), I would look into that first.

The next thing I would do if triangle is not an option is to calculate the centroid of the contour (or blob) and compare that to the center of the minimum bounding rectangle. That should tell you where the bottom of the cone is relative to the minimum rect.
